definition: A chart or system showing the days, weeks, and months of a year; a schedule of planned events.
examples: Check the calendar for the trip dates.
Our class calendar lists all assignments.

extra.memory_tip: Calendar keeps your days in order.

definition: A public festival with music, costumes, rides, and parades.
examples: We ate candyfloss at the seaside carnival.
The carnival parade filled the streets with colour.

definition: Knowledge or skill gained by doing and feeling; to go through or feel something.
examples: Work experience can help you get a job. (noun)
Visitors experienced the art through VR headsets. (verb)

definition: To rule or manage the affairs of a place, people, or organisation.
examples: Citizens elect leaders to govern the country.
Clear rules govern how labs handle chemicals.

definition: A large sea inlet partly surrounded by land; a wide difference or separation between people or ideas.
examples: Fishermen sailed across the gulf.
There’s a gulf between their opinions.

extra.memory_tip: Gulf = a great gap—of water or ideas.

definition: Great speed, often with little thought; hurry.
examples: In his haste, he forgot his ticket.
Haste in science can cause errors.

definition: A large group of people living in one country under one government.
examples: The nation voted on a new law.
Nations meet to discuss climate goals.

extra.memory_tip: Nation = one people under one flag.

definition: To throw or spread things widely in different directions; the spread itself.
examples: The wind scattered the leaves. (verb)
We analysed the scatter of the data points. (noun)

definition: To give up control or stop resisting; the act of giving up.
examples: The army surrendered after a long siege. (verb)
The surrender was signed at noon. (noun)

extra.memory_tip: Surrender = send it over to the other side.

definition: A sudden strong feeling of excitement; to excite greatly.
examples: Riding the rollercoaster was a thrill. (noun)
The announcement thrilled the crowd. (verb)

extra.memory_tip: Thrill = a tingling surge of joy.
